But here’s the thing... that works great _if you’re thin_. If you have a dad bod like me with a good thick layer of fat, the sweat cools your surface, but keeps heat trapped inside. In that case, a hot beverage won’t cool you because the heat has nowhere to go. The added heat will just trigger your body to dump sweat onto already clammy skin. Taking a hot shower, on the other hand, warms the outer layer of fat allowing the capillaries in your skin to dilate. The improved circulation works like a car radiator, allowing your inside and outside to cool more evenly and quickly.

She also taught me that the body's "thermostat" (the heat sensors that identify core temperature and initiate changes) are essentially right behind the breast bone (perhaps not literally, but - ) if you open your jacket up when you enter a warm building from the cold outdoors and allow your chest to register the increased warmth, your body will stop trying to heat you up against cold that is no longer around you. So you won't sweat despite not taking your outdoor gear off completely - which is IMPORTANT, because if you do sweat, when you go outdoors again your sweat can freeze, chilling you much more than simply not having a jacket, and in extreme temperature changes (from 20 indoors to -30 outdoors, for example) it can be genuinely dangerous.

It's important to open your jacket as soon as you come indoors, not waiting until you've warmed up. Because the body's response is delayed, and if you're fully warmed up before you open it, you will be sweating before it stops trying to heat you. That's why the fact that it "thinks" you need heating causes sweat in the first place: because you will get warm enough - then too warm - then sweat to cool off again.
